Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Relationship between diverse male coloration and speciation in darters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Selection on differential reproductive success of males and females (sexual selection) has been linked to speciation by driving divergence in both a male trait and the female preference for that trait. However, this process should not apply to the diversification of traits selected via male-male competition rather than female preference. Such traits may nevertheless facilitate speciation if involved in species recognition, and be favored if mating among species is disadvantageous (i.e., reinforcement against hybridization). This project investigates orangethroat and rainbow darters, representatives of a speciose fish clade with diverse and distinctive male breeding coloration. In both, competition between males affects their reproductive success while female preference does not. The research will incorporate (1) preference experiments to test whether male coloration mediates species recognition, (2) field surveys to examine the factors underlying male color diversification, and (3) a breeding design to measure hybrid inviability and thus the potential for reinforcement.

This project will elucidate the poorly understood relationship between speciation and male-male competition, a major aspect of sexual selection. Additionally, there will be opportunities for science education through participation in public outreach events involving native aquatic fauna, as darters make attractive and accessible subjects for teaching about ecology, evolution, and conservation. Finally, this project will mentor undergraduates in evolutionary concepts and the process of scientific inquiry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sexual selection has long been recognized as a potent agent of speciation, by driving the evolution and diversification of elaborate sexual ornaments. The traditional model for this process is based upon coevolution between a male trait and the female preference for that trait. The potential effects of male preferences and/or male-male competition have received less attention; yet, these factors may modulate or even counter female choice, and understanding them is crucial to forming a complete picture of how sexual selection promotes reproductive isolation.

Darters are a highly speciose group of small, bottom-dwelling freshwater fishes that also exhibit great diversity in male breeding coloration. Our research aimed to investigate the processes of sexual selection and speciation in the orangethroat darter (Etheostoma spectabile) and the closely related rainbow darter (E. caeruleum). The males of both species exhibit bluish and reddish coloration, whereas the females are drab. During the mating season in the spring, males closely pursue gravid females until they are ready to spawn, while guarding them against approaching rivals. These species occur in both allopatry and sympatry; where they are found together reproductive isolation between them is nearly complete.

Our project involved three main experiments:

1) To determine whether male coloration functions in male-male competition, we conducted spawning trials in which multiple male E. spectabile were placed with a single female. We found that the quality and quantity of male coloration was correlated with reproductive success, both in terms of guarding the female against rivals and in spawning. As relatively larger males were also more successful, their coloration may serve to communicate their physical prowess. Previous studies in E. spectabile have not found evidence that females harbor preferences for male size or coloration; thus, male breeding coloration in this species appears to have evolved predominantly due to competition for mates.

2) To investigate the mechanism of behavioral isolation between E. spectabile and E. caeruleum, we performed spawning trials involving three fish: a male and a female E. spectabile, and a rival male that was either another E. spectabile or an E. caeruleum. The trials were repeated in normal light, dim light, and blue light (which prevented the fish from perceiving the reddish parts of their coloration). We found that reproductive isolation between these species was largely maintained by male behavior, in that the male E. spectabile actively pursued the female E. spectabile while the male E. caeruleum did not. Conversely, the female did not exhibit any overt mate choice either within or across species, and invariably spawned with the first male to reach her. Furthermore, males directed most of their attacks towards conspecific males. When the fish were placed under blue light, the males mostly ceased attacking one another, suggesting that reddish coloration mediates male-male species discrimination.

3) To measure the potential costs of hybridization between E. spectabile and E. caeruleum, we created hybrid and purebred offspring from a sympatric population and raised them under common garden conditions. Hatching and survival rates did not differ between hybrid and purebred families. However, we did discover that, in contrast to purebred families, F1 hybrid families were strongly biased towards males. This represents the first evidence that hybridization between closely related darters may be disadvantageous, which would contribute to the reinforcement of behavioral reproductive barriers.
